I am indeed down-hearted when you walk over me.\r\nBut here I\'ll stay, though this stern strikes rocks; and they\r\nbulge through; and oysters come to join me."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 130\r\n\r\nThe Hat\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd now that at the proper time and place, after so long and wide\r\na preliminary cruise, Ahab,--all other whaling waters swept--\r\nseemed to have chased his foe into an oceanfold, to slay him\r\nthe more securely there; now, that he found himself hard\r\nby the very latitude and longitude where his tormenting wound\r\nhad been inflicted; now that a vessel had been spoken which on\r\nthe very day preceding had actually encountered Moby Dick;--\r\nand now that all his successive meetings with various ships\r\ncontrastingly concurred to show the demoniac indifference with which\r\nthe white whale tore his hunters, whether sinning or sinned against;\r\nnow it was that there lurked a something in the old man\'s eyes,\r\nwhich it was hardly sufferable for feeble souls to see.\r\nAs the unsetting polar star, which through the livelong, arctic,\r\nsix months\' night sustains its piercing, steady, central gaze;\r\nso Ahab\'s purpose now fixedly gleamed down upon the constant\r\nmidnight of the gloomy crew.  It domineered above them so,\r\nthat all their bodings, doubts, misgivings, fears, were fain\r\nto hide beneath their souls, and not sprout forth a single\r\nspear or leaf.\r\n\r\nIn this foreshadowing interval, too, all humor, forced\r\nor natural, vanished.  Stubb no more strove to raise a smile;\r\nStarbuck no more strove to check one.  Alike, joy and sorrow,\r\nhope and fear, seemed ground to finest dust, and powdered,\r\nfor the time, in the clamped mortar of Ahab\'s iron soul.\r\nLike machines, they dumbly moved about the deck, ever conscious\r\nthat the old man\'s despot eye was on them.'] This obsession seems to stem from deep-seated anger and malice, which he personally associates with the whale. His quest for Moby Dick is not just a physical pursuit but also a manifestation of his emotional turmoil and delirium.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | ["The White Whale swam before him as the monomaniac incarnation of all\r\nthose malicious agencies which some deep men feel eating in them,\r\ntill they are left living on with half a heart and half a lung.\r\nThat intangible malignity which has been from the beginning; to whose\r\ndominion even the modern Christians ascribe one-half of the worlds;\r\nwhich the ancient Ophites of the east reverenced in their statue devil;--\r\nAhab did not fall down and worship it like them; but deliriously\r\ntransferring its idea to the abhorred white whale, he pitted himself,\r\nall mutilated, against it.  All that most maddens and torments;\r\nall that stirs up the lees of things; all truth with malice in it;\r\nall that cracks the sinews and cakes the brain; all the subtle demonisms\r\nof life and thought; all evil, to crazy Ahab, were visibly personified,\r\nand made practically assailable in Moby Dick.  He piled upon the whale's\r\nwhite hump the sum of all the general rage and hate felt by his whole\r\nrace from Adam down; and then, as if his chest had been a mortar,\r\nhe burst his hot heart's shell upon it.\r\n\r\nIt is not probable that this monomania in him took its instant\r\nrise at the precise time of his bodily dismemberment.\r\nThen, in darting at the monster, knife in hand, he had but\r\ngiven loose to a sudden, passionate, corporal animosity;\r\nand when he received the stroke that tore him, he probably\r\nbut felt the agonizing bodily laceration, but nothing more.\r\nYet, when by this collision forced to turn towards home, and for\r\nlong months of days and weeks, Ahab and anguish lay stretched\r\ntogether in one hammock, rounding in mid winter that dreary,\r\nhowling Patagonian Cape; then it was, that his torn body and gashed\r\nsoul bled into one another; and so interfusing, made him mad." So still and subdued and yet\r\nsomehow preluding was all the scene, and such an incantation of revelry\r\nlurked in the air, that each silent sailor seemed resolved into his\r\nown invisible self.\r\n\r\nI was the attendant or page of Queequeg, while busy at the mat.\r\nAs I kept passing and repassing the filling or woof of marline\r\nbetween the long yarns of the warp, using my own hand for the shuttle,\r\nand as Queequeg, standing sideways, ever and anon slid his heavy\r\noaken sword between the threads, and idly looking off upon\r\nthe water, carelessly and unthinkingly drove home every yarn;\r\nI say so strange a dreaminess did there then reign all over\r\nthe ship and all over the sea, only broken by the intermitting\r\ndull sound of the sword, that it seemed as if this were\r\nthe Loom of Time, and I myself were a shuttle mechanically\r\nweaving and weaving away at the Fates." Not only were the old sails being mended, but new sails\r\nwere coming on board, and bolts of canvas, and coils of rigging;\r\nin short, everything betokened that the ship's preparations were\r\nhurrying to a close.  Captain Peleg seldom or never went ashore,\r\nbut sat in his wigwam keeping a sharp look-out upon the hands:\r\nBildad did all the purchasing and providing at the stores;\r\nand the men employed in the hold and on the rigging were working\r\ntill long after night-fall.\r\n\r\nOn the day following Queequeg's signing the articles,\r\nword was given at all the inns where the ship's company\r\nwere stopping, that their chests must be on board before night,\r\nfor there was no telling how soon the vessel might be sailing.\r\nSo Queequeg and I got down our traps, resolving, however, to sleep\r\nashore till the last.  But it seems they always give very long\r\nnotice in these cases, and the ship did not sail for several days.\r\nBut no wonder; there was a good deal to be done, and there is\r\nno telling how many things to be thought of, before the Pequod\r\nwas fully equipped.\r\n\r\nEvery one knows what a multitude of things--beds, sauce-pans, knives\r\nand forks, shovels and tongs, napkins, nut-crackers, and what not,\r\nare indispensable to the business of housekeeping.  Just so with whaling,\r\nwhich necessitates a three-years' housekeeping upon the wide ocean,\r\nfar from all grocers, costermongers, doctors, bakers, and bankers.\r\nAnd though this also holds true of Enough, that when breakfast\r\nwas over he withdrew like the rest into the public room,\r\nlighted his tomahawk-pipe, and was sitting there quietly\r\ndigesting and smoking with his inseparable hat on, when I\r\nsallied out for a stroll.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 6\r\n\r\nThe Street\r\n\r\n\r\nIf I had been astonished at first catching a glimpse of so outlandish\r\nan individual as Queequeg circulating among the polite society\r\nof a civilized town, that astonishment soon departed upon taking\r\nmy first daylight stroll through the streets of New Bedford.\r\n\r\nIn thoroughfares nigh the docks, any considerable seaport will frequently\r\noffer to view the queerest looking nondescripts from foreign parts.\r\nEven in Broadway and Chestnut streets, Mediterranean mariners will\r\nsometimes jostle the affrighted ladies.  Regent Street is not unknown\r\nto Lascars and Malays; and at Bombay, in the Apollo Green, live Yankees\r\nhave often scared the natives.  But New Bedford beats all Water Street\r\nand Wapping.  In these last-mentioned haunts you see only sailors;\r\nbut in New Bedford, actual cannibals stand chatting at street corners;\r\nsavages outright; many of whom yet carry on their bones unholy flesh.\r\nIt makes a stranger stare.\r\n\r\nBut, besides the Feegeeans, Tongatobooarrs, Erromanggoans, Pannangians,\r\nand Brighggians, and, besides the wild specimens of the whaling-craft\r\nwhich unheeded reel about the streets, you will see other sights still\r\nmore curious, certainly more comical.  There weekly arrive in this town\r\nscores of green Vermonters and New Hampshire men, all athirst for gain\r\nand glory in the fishery.  They are mostly young, of stalwart frames;\r\nfellows who have felled forests, and now seek to drop the axe and snatch\r\nthe whale-lance." | What material is Ahab's prosthetic leg made from?                                     | The provided text indicates that Ahab's prosthetic leg is made from ivory.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                | ['So powerfully did the whole grim aspect of Ahab affect me,\r\nand the livid brand which streaked it, that for the first few moments\r\nI hardly noted that not a little of this overbearing grimness\r\nwas owing to the barbaric white leg upon which he partly stood.\r\nIt had previously come to me that this ivory leg had at sea been\r\nfashioned from the polished bone of the sperm whale\'s jaw.\r\n"Aye, he was dismasted off Japan," said the old Gay-Head Indian once;\r\n"but like his dismasted craft, he shipped another mast without\r\ncoming home for it.  He has a quiver of \'em."\r\n\r\nI was struck with the singular posture he maintained.\r\nUpon each side of the Pequod\'s quarter deck, and pretty close\r\nto the mizzen shrouds, there was an auger hole, bored about half\r\nan inch or so, into the plank.  His bone leg steadied in that hole;\r\none arm elevated, and holding by a shroud; Captain Ahab stood erect,\r\nlooking straight out beyond the ship\'s ever-pitching prow.\r\nThere was an infinity of firmest fortitude, a determinate,\r\nunsurrenderable wilfulness, in the fixed and fearless,\r\nforward dedication of that glance.  Not a word he spoke;\r\nnor did his officers say aught to him; though by all their\r\nminutest gestures and expressions, they plainly showed the uneasy,\r\nif not painful, consciousness of being under a troubled\r\nmaster-eye. And not only that, but moody stricken Ahab stood\r\nbefore them with a crucifixion in his face; in all the nameless\r\nregal overbearing dignity of some mighty woe.\r\n\r\nEre long, from his first visit in the air, he withdrew into his cabin.\r\nBut after that morning, he was every day visible to the crew;\r\neither standing in his pivot-hole, or seated upon an ivory stool he had;\r\nor heavily walking the deck.  As the sky grew less gloomy; indeed, began\r\nto grow a little genial, he became still less and less a recluse;\r\nas if, when the ship had sailed from home, nothing but the dead wintry\r\nbleakness of the sea had then kept him so secluded.' |                                                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |  "He had lighted with such energy upon a thwart\r\nof his boat that his ivory leg had received a half-splintering shock.\r\nAnd when after gaining his own deck, and his own pivot-hole there,\r\nhe so vehemently wheeled round with an urgent command to the steersman\r\n(it was, as ever, something about his not steering inflexibly enough);\r\nthen, the already shaken ivory received such an additional twist\r\nand wrench, that though it still remained entire, and to all\r\nappearances lusty, yet Ahab did not deem it entirely trustworthy.\r\n\r\nAnd, indeed, it seemed small matter for wonder, that for all\r\nhis pervading, mad recklessness, Ahab, did at times give careful\r\nheed to the condition of that dead bone upon which he partly stood.\r\nFor it had not been very long prior to the Pequod's sailing\r\nfrom Nantucket, that he had been found one night lying prone upon\r\nthe ground, and insensible; by some unknown, and seemingly inexplicable,\r\nunimaginable casualty, his ivory limb having been so violently displaced,\r\nthat it had stake-wise smitten, and all but pierced his groin;\r\nnor was it without extreme difficulty that the agonizing wound\r\nwas entirely cured.\r\n\r\nNor, at the time, had it failed to enter his monomaniac mind,\r\nthat all the anguish of that then present suffering was but the\r\ndirect issue of a former woe; | What is the name of the inn where Ishmael first meets Queequeg?                       | The provided context does not specify an inn where Ishmael first meets Queequeg.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          | ["But that was certainly very coolly done by him, and every one\r\nknows that in most people's estimation, to do anything coolly\r\nis to do it genteelly.\r\n\r\nWe will not speak of all Queequeg's peculiarities here;\r\nhow he eschewed coffee and hot rolls, and applied his undivided\r\nattention to beefsteaks, done rare.  Enough, that when breakfast\r\nwas over he withdrew like the rest into the public room,\r\nlighted his tomahawk-pipe, and was sitting there quietly\r\ndigesting and smoking with his inseparable hat on, when I\r\nsallied out for a stroll.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 6\r\n\r\nThe Street\r\n\r\n\r\nIf I had been astonished at first catching a glimpse of so outlandish\r\nan individual as Queequeg circulating among the polite society\r\nof a civilized town, that astonishment soon departed upon taking\r\nmy first daylight stroll through the streets of New Bedford.\r\n\r\nIn thoroughfares nigh the docks, any considerable seaport will frequently\r\noffer to view the queerest looking nondescripts from foreign parts.\r\nEven in Broadway and Chestnut streets, Mediterranean mariners will\r\nsometimes jostle the affrighted ladies.  Regent Street is not unknown\r\nto Lascars and Malays; and at Bombay, in the Apollo Green, live Yankees\r\nhave often scared the natives.  But New Bedford beats all Water Street\r\nand Wapping.  In these last-mentioned haunts you see only sailors;\r\nbut in New Bedford, actual cannibals stand chatting at street corners;\r\nsavages outright; many of whom yet carry on their bones unholy flesh.\r\nIt makes a stranger stare.\r\n\r\nBut, besides the Feegeeans, Tongatobooarrs, Erromanggoans, Pannangians,\r\nand Brighggians, and, besides the wild specimens of the whaling-craft\r\nwhich unheeded reel about the streets, you will see other sights still\r\nmore curious, certainly more comical.  There weekly arrive in this town\r\nscores of green Vermonters and New Hampshire men, all athirst for gain\r\nand glory in the fishery.  They are mostly young, of stalwart frames;\r\nfellows who have felled forests, and now seek to drop the axe and snatch\r\nthe whale-lance." |                                                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |  'Now a certain grand merchant\r\nship once touched at Rokovoko, and its commander--from all accounts,\r\na very stately punctilious gentleman, at least for a sea captain--\r\nthis commander was invited to the wedding feast of Queequeg\'s sister,\r\na pretty young princess just turned of ten.  Well; when all\r\nthe wedding guests were assembled at the bride\'s bamboo cottage,\r\nthis Captain marches in, and being assigned the post of honor,\r\nplaced himself over against the punchbowl, and between\r\nthe High Priest and his majesty the King, Queequeg\'s father.\r\nGrace being said,--for those people have their grace as well as we--\r\nthough Queequeg told me that unlike us, who at such times look\r\ndownwards to our platters, they, on the contrary, copying the ducks,\r\nglance upwards to the great Giver of all feasts--Grace, I say,\r\nbeing said, the High Priest opens the banquet by the immemorial ceremony\r\nof the island; that is, dipping his consecrated and consecrating\r\nfingers into the bowl before the blessed beverage circulates.\r\nSeeing himself placed next the Priest, and noting the ceremony,\r\nand thinking himself--being Captain of a ship--as having plain\r\nprecedence over a mere island King, especially in the King\'s own house--\r\nthe Captain coolly proceeds to wash his hands in the punch bowl;--\r\ntaking it I suppose for a huge finger-glass. "Now," said Queequeg,\r\n"what you tink now?--Didn\'t our people laugh?"\r\n\r\nAt last, passage paid, and luggage safe, we stood on board the schooner.\r\nHoisting sail, it glided down the Acushnet river.  On one side,\r\nNew Bedford rose in terraces of streets, their ice-covered trees all\r\nglittering in the clear, cold air.'] | What is the subject of Father Mapple's sermon in the Whaleman's Chapel?               | The text does not provide specific details about the content of Father Mapple's sermon in the Whaleman's Chapel. However, based on the context, it can be inferred that his sermon likely involves themes related to faith, spirituality, and resilience, as suggested by the imagery of a ship beating against a storm and the angel's face shining upon the ship's deck. The pulpit itself, which is likened to a ship's bow, seems to reinforce this interpretation, suggesting that the sermon may be about leading the world and overcoming adversity.                                                                                                               | ["Methinks my body is but the lees of my better being.\r\nIn fact take my body who will, take it I say, it is not me.\r\nAnd therefore three cheers for Nantucket; and come a stove\r\nboat and stove body when they will, for stave my soul,\r\nJove himself cannot.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 8\r\n\r\nThe Pulpit\r\n\r\n\r\nI had not been seated very long ere a man of a certain venerable\r\nrobustness entered; immediately as the storm-pelted door flew\r\nback upon admitting him, a quick regardful eyeing of him by all\r\nthe congregation, sufficiently attested that this fine old\r\nman was the chaplain.  Yes, it was the famous Father Mapple,\r\nso called by the whalemen, among whom he was a very great favorite.\r\nHe had been a sailor and a harpooneer in his youth, but for\r\nmany years past had dedicated his life to the ministry.\r\nAt the time I now write of, Father Mapple was in the hardy winter\r\nof a healthy old age; that sort of old age which seems merging into\r\na second flowering youth, for among all the fissures of his wrinkles,\r\nthere shone certain mild gleams of a newly developing bloom--\r\nthe spring verdure peeping forth even beneath February's snow.\r\nNo one having previously heard his history, could for the first time\r\nbehold Father Mapple without the utmost interest, because there\r\nwere certain engrafted clerical peculiarities about him,\r\nimputable to that adventurous maritime life he had led.\r\nWhen he entered I observed that he carried no umbrella,\r\nand certainly had not come in his carriage, for his tarpaulin\r\nhat ran down with melting sleet, and his great pilot cloth\r\njacket seemed almost to drag him to the floor with the weight\r\nof the water it had absorbed.  However, hat and coat and\r\novershoes were one by one removed, and hung up in a little\r\nspace in an adjacent corner; when, arrayed in a decent suit,\r\nhe quietly approached the pulpit." |                                                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |  'Father Mapple enjoyed such a wide reputation for sincerity and sanctity,\r\nthat I could not suspect him of courting notoriety by any mere\r\ntricks of the stage.  No, thought I, there must be some sober reason\r\nfor this thing; furthermore, it must symbolize something unseen.\r\nCan it be, then, that by that act of physical isolation,\r\nhe signifies his spiritual withdrawal for the time, from all outward\r\nworldly ties and connexions?  Yes, for replenished with the meat\r\nand wine of the word, to the faithful man of God, this pulpit,\r\nI see, is a self-containing stronghold--a lofty Ehrenbreitstein,\r\nwith a perennial well of water within the walls.\r\n\r\nBut the side ladder was not the only strange feature of the place,\r\nborrowed from the chaplain\'s former sea-farings. Between the marble\r\ncenotaphs on either hand of the pulpit, the wall which formed its back was\r\nadorned with a large painting representing a gallant ship beating against\r\na terrible storm off a lee coast of black rocks and snowy breakers.\r\nBut high above the flying scud and dark-rolling clouds, there floated\r\na little isle of sunlight, from which beamed forth an angel\'s face;\r\nand this bright face shed a distant spot of radiance upon the ship\'s\r\ntossed deck, something like that silver plate now inserted into\r\nthe Victory\'s plank where Nelson fell.  "Ah, noble ship," the angel\r\nseemed to say, "beat on, beat on, thou noble ship, and bear a hardy helm;\r\nfor lo! the sun is breaking through; the clouds are rolling off--\r\nserenest azure is at hand."\r\n\r\nNor was the pulpit itself without a trace of the same\r\nsea-taste that had achieved the ladder and the picture.\r\nIts panelled front was in the likeness of a ship\'s bluff bows,\r\nand the Holy Bible rested on a projecting piece of scroll work,\r\nfashioned after a ship\'s fiddle-headed beak.\r\n\r\nWhat could be more full of meaning?--for the pulpit is ever this\r\nearth\'s foremost part; all the rest comes in its rear; the pulpit\r\nleads the world.'] | Besides Starbuck, who are the second and third mates of the Pequod?                   | In the given context, the second mate is Stubb and the third mate is Flask.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               | ["As a carpenter's nails are divided into wrought nails and cut nails;\r\nso mankind may be similarly divided.  Little Flask was one\r\nof the wrought ones; made to clinch tight and last long.\r\nThey called him King-Post on board of the Pequod; because, in form,\r\nhe could be well likened to the short, square timber known by that name\r\nin Arctic whalers; and which by the means of many radiating side\r\ntimbers inserted into it, serves to brace the ship against the icy\r\nconcussions of those battering seas.\r\n\r\nNow these three mates--Starbuck, Stubb and Flask, were momentous men.\r\nThey it was who by universal prescription commanded three of the Pequod's\r\nboats as headsmen.  In that grand order of battle in which Captain Ahab\r\nwould probably marshal his forces to descend on the whales, these three\r\nheadsmen were as captains of companies.  Or, being armed with their\r\nlong keen whaling spears, they were as a picked trio of lancers;\r\neven as the harpooneers were flingers of javelins.\r\n\r\nAnd since in this famous fishery, each mate or headsman,\r\nlike a Gothic Knight of old, is always accompanied by his\r\nboat-steerer or harpooneer, who in certain conjunctures provides\r\nhim with a fresh lance, when the former one has been badly twisted,\r\nor elbowed in the assault; and moreover, as there generally\r\nsubsists between the two, a close intimacy and friendliness;\r\nit is therefore but meet, that in this place we set down\r\nwho the Pequod's harpooneers were, and to what headsman each\r\nof them belonged.\r\n\r\nFirst of all was Queequeg, whom Starbuck, the chief mate,\r\nhad selected for his squire.  But Queequeg is already known.\r\n\r\nNext was Tashtego, an unmixed Indian from Gay Head, the most westerly\r\npromontory of Martha's Vineyard, where there still exists the last\r\nremnant of a village of red men, which has long supplied the neighboring\r\nisland of Nantucket with many of her most daring harpooneers.\r\nIn the fishery, they usually go by the generic name of\r\nGay-Headers." |                                                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |  '"Starbuck!"\r\n\r\n"Sir?"\r\n\r\n"For the third time my soul\'s ship starts upon this voyage, Starbuck."\r\n\r\n"Aye, sir, thou wilt have it so."\r\n\r\n"Some ships sail from their ports, and ever afterwards\r\nare missing, Starbuck!"\r\n\r\n"Truth, sir:  saddest truth."\r\n\r\n"Some men die at ebb tide; some at low water; some at the full\r\nof the flood;--and I feel now like a billow that\'s all one\r\ncrested comb, Starbuck.  I am old;--shake hands with me, man."\r\n\r\nTheir hands met; their eyes fastened; Starbuck\'s tears the glue.\r\n\r\n"Oh, my captain, my captain!--noble heart--go not--go not!--see, it\'s a\r\nbrave man that weeps; how great the agony of the persuasion then!"\r\n\r\n"Lower away!"-cried Ahab, tossing the mate\'s arm from him.\r\n"Stand by for the crew!"\r\n\r\nIn an instant the boat was pulling round close under the stern.\r\n\r\n"The sharks! the sharks!" cried a voice from the low cabin-window there;\r\n"O master, my master, come back!"\r\n\r\nBut Ahab heard nothing; for his own voice was high-lifted then;\r\nand the boat leaped on.\r\n\r\nYet the voice spake true; for scarce had he pushed from the ship,\r\nwhen numbers of sharks, seemingly rising from out the dark waters\r\nbeneath the hull, maliciously snapped at the blades of the oars,\r\nevery time they dipped in the water; and in this way accompanied\r\nthe boat with their bites.  It is a thing not uncommonly happening\r\nto the whale-boats in those swarming seas; the sharks at times\r\napparently following them in the same prescient way that vultures\r\nhover over the banners When not in use,\r\nthey are kept remarkably clean. This was an easy thing, for the carpenter had been\r\nthrusting his shavings into the furnace throughout the passage.\r\nHere be it said that in a whaling voyage the first fire in the\r\ntry-works has to be fed for a time with wood. Later on, it is hinted that Pip may have had some sort of spiritual or mystical experience while lost at sea, as he seems to have gained some sort of insight or understanding beyond human reason.                                             | ["Some few hands are reserved called shipkeepers, whose province it\r\nis to work the vessel while the boats are pursuing the whale.\r\nAs a general thing, these shipkeepers are as hardy fellows\r\nas the men comprising the boats' crews. It was so in the Pequod\r\nwith the little negro Pippin by nick-name, Pip by abbreviation.\r\nPoor Pip! ye have heard of him before; ye must remember his tambourine\r\non that dramatic midnight, so gloomy-jolly.\r\n\r\nIn outer aspect, Pip and Dough-Boy made a match, like a black pony\r\nand a white one, of equal developments, though of dissimilar color,\r\ndriven in one eccentric span. life's peaceable securities; so that\r\nthe panic-striking business in which he had somehow unaccountably\r\nbecome entrapped, had most sadly blurred his brightness; though, as ere\r\nlong will be | What does the white whale, Moby Dick, seem to symbolize to Captain Ahab?              | In the provided context, it appears that Captain Ahab perceives Moby Dick as a personification of all evil and malice that torments him and his people. He transfers this malevolence onto Moby Dick, making it practically assailable for him. This is indicated by statements such as "All that most maddens and torments...all the subtle demonisms of life and thought; all evil" being visibly personified in Moby Dick, and Ahab's declaration that he piled upon the whale's white hump "the sum of all the general rage and hate felt by his whole race from Adam down."                                                                                          | ["The White Whale swam before him as the monomaniac incarnation of all\r\nthose malicious agencies which some deep men feel eating in them,\r\ntill they are left living on with half a heart and half a lung.\r\nThat intangible malignity which has been from the beginning; to whose\r\ndominion even the modern Christians ascribe one-half of the worlds;\r\nwhich the ancient Ophites of the east reverenced in their statue devil;--\r\nAhab did not fall down and worship it like them; but deliriously\r\ntransferring its idea to the abhorred white whale, he pitted himself,\r\nall mutilated, against it.  All that most maddens and torments;\r\nall that stirs up the lees of things; all truth with malice in it;\r\nall that cracks the sinews and cakes the brain; all the subtle demonisms\r\nof life and thought; all evil, to crazy Ahab, were visibly personified,\r\nand made practically assailable in Moby Dick.  He piled upon the whale's\r\nwhite hump the sum of all the general rage and hate felt by his whole\r\nrace from Adam down; and then, as if his chest had been a mortar,\r\nhe burst his hot heart's shell upon it.\r\n\r\nIt is not probable that this monomania in him took its instant\r\nrise at the precise time of his bodily dismemberment.\r\nThen, in darting at the monster, knife in hand, he had but\r\ngiven loose to a sudden, passionate, corporal animosity;\r\nand when he received the stroke that tore him, he probably\r\nbut felt the agonizing bodily laceration, but nothing more.\r\nYet, when by this collision forced to turn towards home, and for\r\nlong months of days and weeks, Ahab and anguish lay stretched\r\ntogether in one hammock, rounding in mid winter that dreary,\r\nhowling Patagonian Cape; then it was, that his torn body and gashed\r\nsoul bled into one another; and so interfusing, made him mad." |                                                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |  'It is then they change places;\r\nand the headsman, the chief officer of the little craft, takes his\r\nproper station in the bows of the boat.\r\n\r\nNow, I care not who maintains the contrary, but all this\r\nis both foolish and unnecessary.  The headsman should stay\r\nin the bows from first to last; he should both dart the harpoon\r\nand the lance, and no rowing whatever should be expected\r\nof him, except under circumstances obvious to any fisherman.\r\nI know that this would sometimes involve a slight loss of speed\r\nin the chase; but long experience in various whalemen of more\r\nthan one nation has convinced me that in the vast majority\r\nof failures in the fishery, it has not by any means been so much\r\nthe speed of the whale as the before described exhaustion\r\nof the harpooneer that has caused them.\r\n\r\nTo insure the greatest efficiency in the dart, the harpooneers\r\nof this world must start to their feet from out of idleness,\r\nand not from out of toil.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 63\r\n\r\nThe Crotch\r\n\r\n\r\nOut of the trunk, the branches grow; out of them, the twigs.\r\nSo, in productive subjects, grow the chapters.\r\n\r\nThe crotch alluded to on a previous page deserves independent mention.\r\nIt is a notched stick of a peculiar form, some two feet\r\nin length, which is perpendicularly inserted into the starboard\r\ngunwale near the bow, for the purpose of furnishing a rest\r\nfor the wooden extremity of the harpoons, whose other naked,\r\nbarbed end slopingly projects from the prow.  Thereby the weapon\r\nis instantly at hand to its hurler, who snatches it up as readily\r\nfrom its rest as a backwoodsman swings his rifle from the wall.\r\nIt is customary to have two harpoons reposing in the crotch,\r\nrespectively called the first and second irons.\r\n\r\nBut these two harpoons, each by its own cord, are both connected\r\nwith the line; the object being this:  to dart them both,\r\nif possible, one instantly after the other into the same whale;\r\nso that if, in the coming drag, one should draw out, the other\r\nmay still retain a hold.  It is a doubling of the chances.'] His role and characteristics beyond this are not explicitly stated in the given context.                                                                                                                                                                                                | ["But one cannot sustain an indifferent air concerning Fedallah.  He was\r\nsuch a creature as civilized, domestic people in the temperate zone\r\nonly see in their dreams, and that but dimly; but the like of whom\r\nnow and then glide among the unchanging Asiatic communities,\r\nespecially the Oriental isles to the east of the continent--\r\nthose insulated, immemorial, unalterable countries, which even in\r\nthese modern days still preserve much of the ghostly aboriginalness\r\nof earth's primal generations, when the memory of the first\r\nman was a distinct recollection, and all men his descendants,\r\nunknowing whence he came, eyed each other as real phantoms, and asked\r\nof the sun and the moon why they were created and to what end;\r\nwhen though, according to Genesis, the angels indeed consorted with\r\nthe daughters of men, the devils also, add the uncanonical Robbins,\r\nindulged in mundane amours.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 51\r\n\r\nThe Spirit-Spout\r\n\r\n\r\nDays, weeks passed, and under easy sail, the ivory Pequod\r\nhad slowly swept across four several cruising-grounds;\r\nthat off the Azores; off the Cape de Verdes; on the Plate\r\n(so called), being off the mouth of the Rio de la Plata;\r\nand the Carrol Ground, an unstaked, watery locality,\r\nsoutherly from St. Helena.\r\n\r\nIt was while gliding through these latter waters that one\r\nserene and moonlight night, when all the waves rolled by like\r\nscrolls of silver; and, by their soft, suffusing seethings,\r\nmade what seemed a silvery silence, not a solitude; on such a\r\nsilent night a silvery jet was seen far in advance of the white\r\nbubbles at the bow.  Lit up by the moon, it looked celestial;\r\nseemed some plumed and glittering god uprising from the sea.\r\nFedallah first descried this jet.  For of these moonlight nights,\r\nit was his wont to mount to the main-mast head, and stand\r\na look-out there, with the same precision as if it had been day.\r\nAnd yet, though herds of whales were seen by night, not one\r\nwhaleman in a hundred would venture a lowering for them." But, in the end, it all came out;\r\nthis one matter did, at least.  That direful mishap was at the bottom\r\nof his temporary recluseness. | What is the name of Captain Ahab's whaling ship?                                      | The text does not provide a specific name for Captain Ahab's whaling ship.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                | ['I am indeed down-hearted when you walk over me.\r\nBut here I\'ll stay, though this stern strikes rocks; and they\r\nbulge through; and oysters come to join me."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 130\r\n\r\nThe Hat\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd now that at the proper time and place, after so long and wide\r\na preliminary cruise, Ahab,--all other whaling waters swept--\r\nseemed to have chased his foe into an oceanfold, to slay him\r\nthe more securely there; now, that he found himself hard\r\nby the very latitude and longitude where his tormenting wound\r\nhad been inflicted; now that a vessel had been spoken which on\r\nthe very day preceding had actually encountered Moby Dick;--\r\nand now that all his successive meetings with various ships\r\ncontrastingly concurred to show the demoniac indifference with which\r\nthe white whale tore his hunters, whether sinning or sinned against;\r\nnow it was that there lurked a something in the old man\'s eyes,\r\nwhich it was hardly sufferable for feeble souls to see.\r\nAs the unsetting polar star, which through the livelong, arctic,\r\nsix months\' night sustains its piercing, steady, central gaze;\r\nso Ahab\'s purpose now fixedly gleamed down upon the constant\r\nmidnight of the gloomy crew.  It domineered above them so,\r\nthat all their bodings, doubts, misgivings, fears, were fain\r\nto hide beneath their souls, and not sprout forth a single\r\nspear or leaf.\r\n\r\nIn this foreshadowing interval, too, all humor, forced\r\nor natural, vanished.  Stubb no more strove to raise a smile;\r\nStarbuck no more strove to check one.  Alike, joy and sorrow,\r\nhope and fear, seemed ground to finest dust, and powdered,\r\nfor the time, in the clamped mortar of Ahab\'s iron soul.\r\nLike machines, they dumbly moved about the deck, ever conscious\r\nthat the old man\'s despot eye was on them.\r\n\r\nBut did you deeply scan him in his more secret confidential\r\nhours when he thought no glance but one was on him;\r\nthen you would have seen that even as Ahab\'s eyes so awed\r\nthe crew\'s, the inscrutable Parsee\'s glance awed his;\r\nor somehow, at least, in some wild way, at times affected it.\r\nSuch an added, gliding strangeness began to invest the thin\r\nFedallah now; such ceaseless shudderings shook him;\r\nthat the men looked dubious at him; half uncertain,\r\nas it seemed, whether indeed he were a mortal substance,\r\nor else a tremulous shadow cast upon the deck by some unseen\r\nbeing\'s body.  And that shadow was always hovering there.\r\nFor not by night, even, had Fedallah ever certainly been known\r\nto slumber, or go below.  He would stand still for hours:\r\nbut never sat or leaned; his wan but wondrous eyes did plainly say--\r\nWe two watchmen never rest.\r\n\r\nNor, at any time, by night or day could the mariners\r\nnow step upon the deck, unless Ahab was before them;\r\neither standing in his pivot-hole, or exactly pacing the planks\r\nbetween two undeviating limits,--the main-mast and the mizen;\r\nor else they saw him standing in the cabin-scuttle,--his living\r\nfoot advanced upon the deck, as if to step; his hat slouched\r\nheavily over his eyes; so that however motionless he stood,\r\nhowever the days and nights were added on, that he had not\r\nswung in his hammock; yet hidden beneath that slouching hat,\r\nthey could never tell unerringly whether, for all this, his eyes\r\nwere really closed at times; or whether he was still intently\r\nscanning them; no matter, though he stood so in the scuttle\r\nfor a whole hour on the stretch, and the unheeded night-damp\r\ngathered in beads of dew upon that stone-carved coat and hat.\r\nThe clothes that the night had wet, the next day\'s sunshine\r\ndried upon him; and so, day after day, and night after night;\r\nhe went no more beneath the planks; whatever he wanted from\r\nthe cabin that thing he sent for.\r\n\r\nHe ate in the same open air; that is, his two only meals,--\r\nbreakfast and dinner:  supper he never touched; nor reaped\r\nhis beard; which darkly grew all gnarled, as unearthed roots\r\nof trees blown over, which still grow idly on at naked base,\r\nthough perished in the upper verdure.  But though his whole\r\nlife was now become one watch on deck; and though the Parsee\'s\r\nmystic watch was without intermission as his own; yet these two\r\nnever seemed to speak--one man to the other--unless at long\r\nintervals some passing unmomentous matter made it necessary.\r\nThough such a potent spell seemed secretly to join the twain;\r\nopenly, and to the awe-struck crew, they seemed pole-like asunder.\r\nIf by day they chanced to speak one word; by night, dumb men\r\nwere both, so far as concerned the slightest verbal interchange.\r\nAt times, for longest hours, without a single hail, they stood\r\nfar parted in the starlight; Ahab in his scuttle, the Parsee\r\nby the main-mast; but still fixedly gazing upon each other;\r\nas if in the Parsee Ahab saw his forethrown shadow, in Ahab\r\nthe Parsee his abandoned substance.\r\n\r\nAnd yet, somehow, did Ahab--in his own proper self, as daily, hourly,\r\nand every instant, commandingly revealed to his subordinates,--\r\nAhab seemed an independent lord; the Parsee but his slave.\r\nStill again both seemed yoked together, and an unseen\r\ntyrant driving them; the lean shade siding the solid rib.\r\nFor be this Parsee what he may, all rib and keel was solid Ahab.\r\n\r\nAt the first faintest glimmering of the dawn, his iron voice was\r\nheard from aft,--"Man the mast-heads!"--and all through the day,\r\ntill after sunset and after twilight, the same voice every hour,\r\nat the striking of the helmsman\'s bell, was heard--"What d\'ye see?--\r\nsharp! sharp! sharp!"\r\n\r\nBut when three or four days had slided by, after meeting\r\nthe children-seeking Rachel; and no spout had yet been seen;\r\nthe monomaniac old man seemed distrustful of his crew\'s fidelity;\r\nat least, of nearly all except the Pagan harpooneers; he seemed\r\nto doubt, even, whether Stubb and Flask might not willingly overlook\r\nthe sight he sought.  But if these suspicions were really his,\r\nhe sagaciously refrained from verbally expressing them,\r\nhowever his actions might seem to hint them.\r\n\r\n"I will have the first sight of the whale myself,"--\r\nhe said.  "Aye!  Ahab must have the doubloon! and with\r\nhis own hands he rigged a nest of basketed bowlines;\r\nand sending a hand aloft, with a single sheaved block,\r\nto secure to the mainmast head, he received the two ends of\r\nthe downwardreeved rope; and attaching one to his basket prepared\r\na pin for the other end, in order to fasten it at the rail.\r\nThis done, with that end yet in his hand and standing beside the pin,\r\nhe looked round upon his crew, sweeping from one to the other;\r\npausing his glance long upon Daggoo, Queequeg, Tashtego;\r\nbut shunning Fedallah; and then settling his firm relying eye\r\nupon the chief mate, said,--"Take the rope, sir--I give it into\r\nthy hands, Starbuck."  Then arranging his person in the basket,\r\nhe gave the word for them to hoist him to his perch, Starbuck being\r\nthe one who secured the rope at last; and afterwards stood near it.\r\nAnd thus, with one hand clinging round the royal mast,\r\nAhab gazed abroad upon the sea for miles and miles,--ahead astern,\r\nthis side, and that,--within the wide expanded circle commanded\r\nat so great a height.\r\n\r\nWhen in working with his hands at some lofty almost isolated place\r\nin the rigging, which chances to afford no foothold, the sailor\r\nat sea is hoisted up to that spot, and sustained there by the rope;\r\nunder these circumstances, its fastened end on deck is always given\r\nin strict charge to some one man who has the special watch of it.\r\nBecause in such a wilderness of running rigging, whose various\r\ndifferent relations aloft cannot always be infallibly discerned\r\nby what is seen of them at the deck; and when the deck-ends of these\r\nropes are being every few minutes cast down from the fastenings,\r\nit would be but a natural fatality, if, unprovided with a\r\nconstant watchman, the hoisted sailor should by some carelessness\r\nof the crew be cast adrift and fall all swooping to the sea.\r\nSo Ahab\'s proceedings in this matter were not unusual;\r\nthe only strange thing about them seemed to be, that Starbuck,\r\nalmost the one only man who had ever ventured to oppose him\r\nwith anything in the slightest degree approaching to decision--\r\none of those too, whose faithfulness on the look-out he had seemed\r\nto doubt somewhat; it was strange, that this was the very man\r\nhe should select for his watchman; freely giving his whole life\r\ninto such an otherwise distrusted person\'s hands.\r\n\r\nNow, the first time Ahab was perched aloft; ere he had been there\r\nten minutes; one of those red-billed savage sea-hawks which so often\r\nfly incommodiously close round the manned mast-heads of whalemen\r\nin these latitudes; one of these birds came wheeling and screaming\r\nround his head in a maze of untrackably swift circlings.\r\nThen it darted a thousand feet straight up into the air;\r\nthen spiralized downwards, and went eddying again round his head.\r\n\r\nBut with his gaze fixed upon the dim and distant horizon,\r\nAhab seemed not to mark this wild bird; nor, indeed, would any\r\none else have marked it much, it being no uncommon circumstance;\r\nonly now almost the least heedful eye seemed to see some sort\r\nof cunning meaning in almost every sight.\r\n\r\n"Your hat, your hat, sir!" suddenly cried the Sicilian seaman,\r\nwho being posted at the mizen-mast-head, stood directly behind Ahab,\r\nthough somewhat lower than his level, and with a deep gulf\r\nof air dividing them.\r\n\r\nBut already the sable wing was before the old man\'s eyes;\r\nthe long hooked bill at his head:  with a scream, the black\r\nhawk darted away with his prize.\r\n\r\nAn eagle flew thrice round Tarquin\'s head, removing his cap to\r\nreplace it, and thereupon Tanaquil, his wife, declared that Tarquin\r\nwould be king of Rome.  But only by the replacing of the cap\r\nwas that omen accounted good.  Ahab\'s hat was never restored;\r\nthe wild hawk flew on and on with it; far in advance of the prow:\r\nand at last disappeared; while from the point of that disappearance,\r\na minute black spot was dimly discerned, falling from that vast\r\nheight into the sea.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 131\r\n\r\nThe Pequod Meets The Delight\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe intense Pequod sailed on; the rolling waves and days went by;\r\nthe life-buoy-coffin still lightly swung; and another ship,\r\nmost miserably misnamed the Delight, was descried.\r\nAs she drew nigh, all eyes were fixed upon her broad beams,\r\ncalled shears, which, in some whaling-ships, cross the quarter-deck\r\nat the height of eight or nine feet; serving to carry the spare,\r\nunrigged, or disabled boats.\r\n\r\nUpon the stranger\'s shears were beheld the shattered, white ribs,\r\nand some few splintered planks, of what had once been a whale-boat;\r\nbut you now saw through this wreck, as plainly as you see through\r\nthe peeled, half-unhinged, and bleaching skeleton of a horse.\r\n\r\n"Hast seen the White Whale?"\r\n\r\n"Look!" replied the hollow-cheeked captain from his taffrail;\r\nand with his trumpet he pointed to the wreck.\r\n\r\n"Hast killed him?"\r\n\r\n"The harpoon is not yet forged that will ever will do that,"\r\nanswered the other, sadly glancing upon a rounded hammock on\r\nthe deck, whose gathered sides some noiseless sailors were busy\r\nin sewing together.\r\n\r\n"Not forged!" and snatching Perth\'s levelled iron from the crotch,\r\nAhab held it out, exclaiming--"Look ye, Nantucketer; here in this\r\nhand I hold his death!  Tempered in blood, and tempered by lightning\r\nare these barbs; and I swear to temper them triply in that hot place\r\nbehind the fin, where the White Whale most feels his accursed life!"\r\n\r\n"Then God keep thee, old man--see\'st thou that"--\r\npointing to the hammock--"I bury but one of five stout men,\r\nwho were alive only yesterday; but were dead ere night.\r\nOnly that one I bury; the rest were buried before they died;\r\nyou sail upon their tomb."  Then turning to his crew--"Are\r\nye ready there? place the plank then on the rail, and lift\r\nthe body; so, then--Oh!  God"--advancing towards the hammock\r\nwith uplifted hands--"may the resurrection and the life-"\r\n\r\n"Brace forward!  Up helm!" | What is Queequeg's profession and where is he from?                                   | Queequeg is a native of Kokovoko, an island far away to the West and South. He was originally a High Chief and a King, but later became a whaleman on a Sag Harbor ship. This information can be inferred from the provided context where it states that he sought a passage to Christian lands, was initially rejected due to the ship having its full complement of seamen, but vowed a vow and ultimately joined the crew as a whaleman.                                                                                                                                                                                                                               | ["Though at the time I but ill comprehended not a few of his words,\r\nyet subsequent disclosures, when I had become more familiar\r\nwith his broken phraseology, now enable me to present the whole\r\nstory such as it may prove in the mere skeleton I give.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 12\r\n\r\nBiographical\r\n\r\n\r\nQueequeg was a native of Kokovoko, an island far away to the West\r\nand South.  It is not down on any map; true places never are.\r\n\r\nWhen a new-hatched savage running wild about his native woodlands\r\nin a grass clout, followed by the nibbling goats, as if he were\r\na green sapling; even then, in Queequeg's ambitious soul,\r\nlurked a strong desire to see something more of Christendom\r\nthan a specimen whaler or two.  His father was a High Chief,\r\na King; his uncle a High Priest; and on the maternal side\r\nhe boasted aunts who were the wives of unconquerable warriors.\r\nThere was excellent blood in his veins--royal stuff;\r\nthough sadly vitiated, I fear, by the cannibal propensity\r\nhe nourished in his untutored youth.\r\n\r\nA Sag Harbor ship visited his father's bay, and Queequeg sought\r\na passage to Christian lands.  But the ship, having her full\r\ncomplement of seamen, spurned his suit; and not all the King\r\nhis father's influence could prevail.  But Queequeg vowed a vow.\r\nAlone in his canoe, he paddled off to a distant strait, which he\r\nknew the ship must pass through when she quitted the island.\r\nOn one side was a coral reef; on the other a low tongue of land,\r\ncovered with mangrove thickets that grew out into the water.\r\nHiding his canoe, still afloat, among these thickets, with its\r\nprow seaward, he sat down in the stern, paddle low in hand;\r\nand when the ship was gliding by, like a flash he darted out;\r\ngained her side; with one backward dash of his foot capsized\r\nand sank his canoe; climbed up the chains; and throwing himself\r\nat full length upon the deck, grappled a ring-bolt there,\r\nand swore not to let it go, though hacked in pieces.\r\n\r\nIn vain the captain threatened to throw him overboard; suspended a\r\ncutlass over his naked wrists; Queequeg was the son of a King,\r\nand Queequeg budged not.  Struck by his desperate dauntlessness,\r\nand his wild desire to visit Christendom, the captain at last relented,\r\nand told him he might make himself at home.  But this fine young savage--\r\nthis sea Prince of Wales, never saw the Captain's cabin.\r\nThey put him down among the sailors, and made a whaleman of him.\r\nBut like Czar Peter content to toil in the shipyards of foreign cities,\r\nQueequeg disdained no seeming ignominy, if thereby he might\r\nhappily gain the power of enlightening his untutored countrymen.\r\nFor at bottom--so he told me--he was actuated by a profound\r\ndesire to learn among the Christians, the arts whereby to make\r\nhis people still happier than they were; and more than that,\r\nstill better than they were. |                                                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |  'shame!"\r\n\r\nDuring all this, Queequeg lay with closed eyes, as if in a dream.\r\nPip was led away, and the sick man was replaced in his hammock.\r\n\r\nBut now that he had apparently made every preparation for death;\r\nnow that his coffin was proved a good fit, Queequeg suddenly rallied;\r\nsoon there seemed no need of the carpenter\'s box; and thereupon,\r\nwhen some expressed their delighted surprise, he, in substance,\r\nsaid, that the cause of his sudden convalescence was this;--\r\nat a critical moment, he had just recalled a little duty ashore, which he\r\nwas leaving undone; and therefore had changed his mind about dying:\r\nhe could not die yet, he averred.  They asked him, then, whether to\r\nlive or die was a matter of his own sovereign will and pleasure.\r\nHe answered, certainly.  In a word, it was Queequeg\'s conceit,\r\nthat if a man made up his mind to live, mere sickness could not kill him:\r\nnothing but a whale, or a gale, or some violent, ungovernable,\r\nunintelligent destroyer of that sort.\r\n\r\nNow, there is this noteworthy difference between savage and civilized;\r\nthat while a sick, civilized man may be six months convalescing,\r\ngenerally speaking, a sick savage is almost half-well again\r\nin a day.  So, in good time my Queequeg gained strength;\r\nand at length after sitting on the windlass for a few indolent days\r\n(but eating with a vigorous appetite) he suddenly leaped to his feet,\r\nthrew out his arms and legs, gave himself a good stretching, yawned a\r\nlittle bit, and then springing into the head of his hoisted boat,\r\nand poising a harpoon, pronounced himself fit for a fight.\r\n\r\nWith a wild whimsiness, he now used his coffin for a sea-chest;\r\nand emptying into it his canvas bag of clothes, set them in order there.\r\nMany spare hours he spent, in carving the lid with all manner of grotesque\r\nfigures and drawings; and it seemed that hereby he was striving,\r\nin his rude way, to copy parts of the twisted tattooing on his body.\r\nAnd this tattooing had been the work of a departed prophet and seer\r\nof his island, who, by those hieroglyphic marks, had written\r\nout on his body a complete theory of the heavens and the earth,\r\nand a mystical treatise on the art of attaining truth; so that Queequeg\r\nin his own proper person was a riddle to unfold; a wondrous work\r\nin one volume; but whose mysteries not even himself could read,\r\nthough his own live heart beat against them; and these mysteries\r\nwere therefore destined in the end to moulder away with the living\r\nparchment whereon they were inscribed, and so be unsolved to the last.\r\nAnd this thought it must have been which suggested to Ahab that wild\r\nexclamation of his, when one morning turning away from surveying poor\r\nQueequeg--"Oh, devilish tantalization of the gods!"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 111\r\n\r\nThe Pacific\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen gliding by the Bashee isles we emerged at last upon the great\r\nSouth Sea; were it not for other things I could have greeted my dear\r\nPacific with uncounted thanks, for now the long supplication of my youth\r\nwas answered; that serene ocean rolled eastwards from me a thousand\r\nleagues of blue.\r\n\r\nThere is, one knows not what sweet mystery about this sea,\r\nwhose gently awful stirrings seems to speak of some hidden soul beneath;\r\nlike those fabled undulations of the Ephesian sod over the buried\r\nEvangelist St. John.  And meet it is, that over these sea-pastures,\r\nwide-rolling watery prairies and Potters\' Fields of all four continents,\r\nthe waves should rise and fall, and ebb and flow unceasingly;\r\nfor here, millions of mixed shades and shadows, drowned dreams,\r\nsomnambulisms, reveries; all that we call lives and souls,\r\nlie dreaming, dreaming, still; tossing like slumberers in their beds;\r\nthe ever-rolling waves but made so by their restlessness.\r\n\r\nTo any meditative Magian rover, this serene Pacific, once beheld,\r\nmust ever after be the sea of his adoption.  It rolls the midmost\r\nwaters of the world, the Indian ocean and Atlantic being but its arms.\r\nThe same waves wash the moles of the new-built California towns,\r\nbut yesterday planted by the recentest race of men and lave the faded\r\nbut still gorgeous skirts of Asiatic lands, older than Abraham;\r\nwhile all between float milky-ways of coral isles, and low-lying, endless,\r\nunknown Archipelagoes, and impenetrable Japans.  Thus this mysterious,\r\ndivine Pacific zones the world\'s whole bulk about; makes all\r\ncoasts one bay to it; seems the tide-beating heart of earth.\r\nLifted by those eternal swells, you needs must own the seductive god,\r\nbowing your head to Pan.\r\n\r\nBut few thoughts of Pan stirred Ahab\'s brain, as standing, like an iron\r\nstatue at his accustomed place beside the mizen rigging, with one\r\nnostril he unthinkingly snuffed the sugary musk from the Bashee isles\r\n(in whose sweet woods mild lovers must be walking), and with\r\nthe other consciously inhaled the salt breath of the new found sea;\r\nthat sea in which the hated White Whale must even then be swimming.\r\nLaunched at length upon these almost final waters, and gliding\r\ntowards the Japanese cruising-ground, the old man\'s purpose\r\nintensified itself.  His firm lips met like the lips of a vice;\r\nthe Delta of his forehead\'s veins swelled like overladen brooks;\r\nin his very sleep, his ringing cry ran through the vaulted hull,\r\n"Stern all! the White Whale spouts thick blood!"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 112\r\n\r\nThe Blacksmith\r\n\r\n\r\nAvailing himself of the mild, summer-cool weather that now reigned\r\nin these latitudes, and in preparation for the peculiarly active\r\npursuits shortly to be anticipated, Perth, the begrimed, blistered\r\nold blacksmith, had not removed his portable forge to the hold again,\r\nafter concluding his contributory work for Ahab\'s leg, but still\r\nretained it on deck, fast lashed to ringbolts by the foremast;\r\nbeing now almost incessantly invoked by the headsmen, and harpooneers,\r\nand bowsmen to do some little job for them; altering, or repairing,\r\nor new shaping their various weapons and boat furniture.\r\nOften he would be surrounded by an eager circle, all waiting\r\nto be served; holding boat-spades, pikeheads, harpoons, and lances,\r\nand jealously watching his every sooty movement, as he toiled.\r\nNevertheless, this old man\'s was a patient hammer wielded by a\r\npatient arm.  No murmur, no impatience, no petulance did come\r\nfrom him.  Silent, slow, and solemn; bowing over still further his\r\nchronically broken back, he toiled away, as if toil were life itself,\r\nand the heavy beating of his hammer the heavy beating of his heart.\r\nAnd so it was.--Most miserable!\r\n\r\nA peculiar walk in this old man, a certain slight but painful\r\nappearing yawing in his gait, had at an early period of the voyage\r\nexcited the curiosity of the mariners.  And to the importunity\r\nof their persisted questionings he had finally given in;\r\nand so it came to pass that every one now knew the shameful\r\nstory of his wretched fate.\r\n\r\nBelated, and not innocently, one bitter winter\'s midnight,\r\non the road running between two country towns, the blacksmith\r\nhalf-stupidly felt the deadly numbness stealing over him,\r\nand sought refuge in a leaning, dilapidated barn.\r\nThe issue was, the loss of the extremities of both feet.\r\nOut of this revelation, part by part, at last came out the four\r\nacts of the gladness, and the one long, and as yet uncatastrophied\r\nfifth act of the grief of his life\'s drama.\r\n\r\nHe was an old man, who, at the age of nearly sixty, had postponedly\r\nencountered that thing in sorrow\'s technicals called ruin.\r\nHe had been an artisan of famed excellence, and with plenty\r\nto do; owned a house and garden; embraced a youthful,\r\ndaughter-like, loving wife, and three blithe, ruddy children;\r\nevery Sunday went to a cheerful-looking church, planted in a grove.\r\nBut one night, under cover of darkness, and further concealed\r\nin a most cunning disguisement, a desperate burglar slid\r\ninto his happy home, and robbed them all of everything.\r\nAnd darker yet to tell, the blacksmith himself did\r\nignorantly conduct this burglar into his family\'s heart.\r\nIt was the Bottle Conjuror!  Upon the opening of that fatal cork,\r\nforth flew the fiend, and shrivelled up his home.  Now, for prudent,\r\nmost wise, and economic reasons, the blacksmith\'s shop was in\r\nthe basement of his dwelling, but with a separate entrance to it;\r\nso that always had the young and loving healthy wife listened\r\nwith no unhappy nervousness, but with vigorous pleasure,\r\nto the stout ringing of her young-armed old husband\'s hammer;\r\nwhose reverberations, muffled by passing through the floors\r\nand walls, came up to her, not unsweetly, in her nursery;\r\nand so, to stout Labor\'s iron lullaby, the blacksmith\'s infants\r\nwere rocked to slumber.\r\n\r\nOh, woe on woe!  Oh, Death, why canst thou not sometimes be timely?\r\nHadst thou taken this old blacksmith to thyself ere his full ruin\r\ncame upon him, then had the young widow had a delicious grief,\r\nand her orphans a truly venerable, legendary sire to dream of in\r\ntheir after years; and all of them a care-killing competency.\r\nBut Death plucked down some virtuous elder brother, on whose whistling\r\ndaily toil solely hung the responsibilities of some other family,\r\nand left the worse than useless old man standing, till the hideous\r\nrot of life should make him easier to harvest.\r\n\r\nWhy tell the whole?  The blows of the basement hammer every day\r\ngrew more and more between; and each blow every day grew fainter\r\nthan the last; the wife sat frozen at the window, with tearless eyes,\r\nglitteringly gazing into the weeping faces of her children;\r\nthe bellows fell; the forge choked up with cinders; the house\r\nwas sold; the mother dived down into the long church-yard grass;\r\nher children twice followed her thither; and the houseless,\r\nfamilyless old man staggered off a vagabond in crape; his every\r\nwoe unreverenced; his grey head a scorn to flaxen curls!\r\n\r\nDeath seems the only desirable sequel for a career like this;\r\nbut Death is only a launching into the region of the strange Untried;\r\nit is but the first salutation to the possibilities\r\nof the immense Remote, the Wild, the Watery, the Unshored;\r\ntherefore, to the death-longing eyes of such men, who still\r\nhave left in them some interior compunctions against suicide,\r\ndoes the all-contributed and all-receptive ocean alluringly spread\r\nforth his whole plain of unimaginable, taking terrors, and wonderful,\r\nnew-life adventures; and from the hearts of infinite Pacifics,\r\nthe thousand mermaids sing to them--"Come hither, broken-hearted;\r\nhere is another life without the guilt of intermediate death;\r\nhere are wonders supernatural, without dying for them.\r\nCome hither! In a word, it was Queequeg\'s conceit,\r\nthat if a man made up his mind to live, mere sickness could not kill him:\r\nnothing but a whale, or a gale, or some violent, ungovernable,\r\nunintelligent destroyer of that sort.\r\n\r\nNow, there is this noteworthy difference between savage and civilized;\r\nthat while a sick, civilized man may be six months convalescing,\r\ngenerally speaking, a sick savage is almost half-well again\r\nin a day.  So, in good time my Queequeg gained strength;\r\nand at length after sitting on the windlass for a few indolent days\r\n(but eating with a vigorous appetite) he suddenly leaped to his feet,\r\nthrew out his arms and legs, gave himself a good stretching, yawned a\r\nlittle bit, and then springing into the head of his hoisted boat,\r\nand poising a harpoon, pronounced himself fit for a fight.\r\n\r\nWith a wild whimsiness, he now used his coffin for a sea-chest;\r\nand emptying into it his canvas bag of clothes, set them in order there.\r\nMany spare hours he spent, in carving the lid with all manner of grotesque\r\nfigures and drawings; and it seemed that hereby he was striving,\r\nin his rude way, to copy parts of the twisted tattooing on his body.\r\nAnd this tattooing had been the work of a departed prophet and seer\r\nof his island, who, by those hieroglyphic marks, had written\r\nout on his body a complete theory of the heavens and the earth,\r\nand a mystical treatise on the art of attaining truth; so that Queequeg\r\nin his own proper person was a riddle to unfold; a wondrous work\r\nin one volume; but whose mysteries not even himself could read,\r\nthough his own live heart beat against them; and these mysteries\r\nwere therefore destined in the end to moulder away with the living\r\nparchment whereon they were inscribed, and so be unsolved to the last.\r\nAnd this thought it must have been which suggested to Ahab that wild\r\nexclamation of his, when one morning turning away from surveying poor\r\nQueequeg--"Oh, devilish tantalization of the gods!"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 111\r\n\r\nThe Pacific\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen gliding by the Bashee isles we emerged at last upon the great\r\nSouth Sea; were it not for other things I could have greeted my dear\r\nPacific with uncounted thanks, for now the long supplication of my youth\r\nwas answered; that serene ocean rolled eastwards from me a thousand\r\nleagues of blue.\r\n\r\nThere is, one knows not what sweet mystery about this sea,\r\nwhose gently awful stirrings seems to speak of some hidden soul beneath;\r\nlike those fabled undulations of the Ephesian sod over the buried\r\nEvangelist St. John.  And meet it is, that over these sea-pastures,\r\nwide-rolling watery prairies and Potters\' Fields of all four continents,\r\nthe waves should rise and fall, and ebb and flow unceasingly;\r\nfor here, millions of mixed shades and shadows, drowned dreams,\r\nsomnambulisms, reveries; all that we call lives and souls,\r\nlie dreaming, dreaming, still; tossing like slumberers in their beds;\r\nthe ever-rolling waves but made so by their restlessness.\r\n\r\nTo any meditative Magian rover, this serene Pacific, once beheld,\r\nmust ever after be the sea of his adoption.  It rolls the midmost\r\nwaters of the world, the Indian ocean and Atlantic being but its arms.\r\nThe same waves wash the moles of the new-built California towns,\r\nbut yesterday planted by the recentest race of men and lave the faded\r\nbut still gorgeous skirts of Asiatic lands, older than Abraham;\r\nwhile all between float milky-ways of coral isles, and low-lying, endless,\r\nunknown Archipelagoes, and impenetrable Japans.  Thus this mysterious,\r\ndivine Pacific zones the world\'s whole bulk about; makes all\r\ncoasts one bay to it; seems the tide-beating heart of earth.\r\nLifted by those eternal swells, you needs must own the seductive god,\r\nbowing your head to Pan.\r\n\r\nBut few thoughts of Pan stirred Ahab\'s brain, as standing, like an iron\r\nstatue at his accustomed place beside the mizen rigging, with one\r\nnostril he unthinkingly snuffed the sugary musk from the Bashee isles\r\n(in whose sweet woods mild lovers must be walking), and with\r\nthe other consciously inhaled the salt breath of the new found sea;\r\nthat sea in which the hated White Whale must even then be swimming.\r\nLaunched at length upon these almost final waters, and gliding\r\ntowards the Japanese cruising-ground, the old man\'s purpose\r\nintensified itself.  His firm lips met like the lips of a vice;\r\nthe Delta of his forehead\'s veins swelled like overladen brooks;\r\nin his very sleep, his ringing cry ran through the vaulted hull,\r\n"Stern all! the White Whale spouts thick blood!"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 112\r\n\r\nThe Blacksmith\r\n\r\n\r\nAvailing himself of the mild, summer-cool weather that now reigned\r\nin these latitudes, and in preparation for the peculiarly active\r\npursuits shortly to be anticipated, Perth, the begrimed, blistered\r\nold blacksmith, had not removed his portable forge to the hold again,\r\nafter concluding his contributory work for Ahab\'s leg, but still\r\nretained it on deck, fast lashed to ringbolts by the foremast;\r\nbeing now almost incessantly invoked by the headsmen, and harpooneers,\r\nand bowsmen to do some little job for them; altering, or repairing,\r\nor new shaping their various weapons and boat furniture.\r\nOften he would be surrounded by an eager circle, all waiting\r\nto be served; holding boat-spades, pikeheads, harpoons, and lances,\r\nand jealously watching his every sooty movement, as he toiled.\r\nNevertheless, this old man\'s was a patient hammer wielded by a\r\npatient arm.  No murmur, no impatience, no petulance did come\r\nfrom him.  Silent, slow, and solemn; bowing over still further his\r\nchronically broken back, he toiled away, as if toil were life itself,\r\nand the heavy beating of his hammer the heavy beating of his heart.\r\nAnd so it was.--Most miserable!\r\n\r\nA peculiar walk in this old man, a certain slight but painful\r\nappearing yawing in his gait, had at an early period of the voyage\r\nexcited the curiosity of the mariners.  And to the importunity\r\nof their persisted questionings he had finally given in;\r\nand so it came to pass that every one now knew the shameful\r\nstory of his wretched fate.\r\n\r\nBelated, and not innocently, one bitter winter\'s midnight,\r\non the road running between two country towns, the blacksmith\r\nhalf-stupidly felt the deadly numbness stealing over him,\r\nand sought refuge in a leaning, dilapidated barn.\r\nThe issue was, the loss of the extremities of both feet.\r\nOut of this revelation, part by part, at last came out the four\r\nacts of the gladness, and the one long, and as yet uncatastrophied\r\nfifth act of the grief of his life\'s drama.\r\n\r\nHe was an old man, who, at the age of nearly sixty, had postponedly\r\nencountered that thing in sorrow\'s technicals called ruin.\r\nHe had been an artisan of famed excellence, and with plenty\r\nto do; owned a house and garden; embraced a youthful,\r\ndaughter-like, loving wife, and three blithe, ruddy children;\r\nevery Sunday went to a cheerful-looking church, planted in a grove.\r\nBut one night, under cover of darkness, and further concealed\r\nin a most cunning disguisement, a desperate burglar slid\r\ninto his happy home, and robbed them all of everything.\r\nAnd darker yet to tell, the blacksmith himself did\r\nignorantly conduct this burglar into his family\'s heart.\r\nIt was the Bottle Conjuror!  Upon the opening of that fatal cork,\r\nforth flew the fiend, and shrivelled up his home.  Now, for prudent,\r\nmost wise, and economic reasons, the blacksmith\'s shop was in\r\nthe basement of his dwelling, but with a separate entrance to it;\r\nso that always had the young and loving healthy wife listened\r\nwith no unhappy nervousness, but with vigorous pleasure,\r\nto the stout ringing of her young-armed old husband\'s hammer;\r\nwhose reverberations, muffled by passing through the floors\r\nand walls, came up to her, not unsweetly, in her nursery;\r\nand so, to stout Labor\'s iron lullaby, the blacksmith\'s infants\r\nwere rocked to slumber.\r\n\r\nOh, woe on woe!  Oh, Death, why canst thou not sometimes be timely?\r\nHadst thou taken this old blacksmith to thyself ere his full ruin\r\ncame upon him, then had the young widow had a delicious grief,\r\nand her orphans a truly venerable, legendary sire to dream of in\r\ntheir after years; and all of them a care-killing competency.\r\nBut Death plucked down some virtuous elder brother, on whose whistling\r\ndaily toil solely hung the responsibilities of some other family,\r\nand left the worse than useless old man standing, till the hideous\r\nrot of life should make him easier to harvest.\r\n\r\nWhy tell the whole?  The blows of the basement hammer every day\r\ngrew more and more between; and each blow every day grew fainter\r\nthan the last; the wife sat frozen at the window, with tearless eyes,\r\nglitteringly gazing into the weeping faces of her children;\r\nthe bellows fell; the forge choked up with cinders; the house\r\nwas sold; the mother dived down into the long church-yard grass;\r\nher children twice followed her thither; and the houseless,\r\nfamilyless old man staggered off a vagabond in crape; his every\r\nwoe unreverenced; his grey head a scorn to flaxen curls!\r\n\r\nDeath seems the only desirable sequel for a career like this;\r\nbut Death is only a launching into the region of the strange Untried;\r\nit is but the first salutation to the possibilities\r\nof the immense Remote, the Wild, the Watery, the Unshored;\r\ntherefore, to the death-longing eyes of such men, who still\r\nhave left in them some interior compunctions against suicide,\r\ndoes the all-contributed and all-receptive ocean alluringly spread\r\nforth his whole plain of unimaginable, taking terrors, and wonderful,\r\nnew-life adventures; and from the hearts of infinite Pacifics,\r\nthe thousand mermaids sing to them--"Come hither, broken-hearted;\r\nhere is another life without the guilt of intermediate death;\r\nhere are wonders supernatural, without dying for them.\r\nCome hither! His father was a High Chief,\r\na King; his uncle a High Priest; and on the maternal side\r\nhe boasted aunts who were the wives of unconquerable warriors.\r\nThere was excellent blood in his veins--royal stuff;\r\nthough sadly vitiated, I fear, by the cannibal propensity\r\nhe nourished in his untutored youth.\r\n\r\nA Sag Harbor ship visited his father's bay, and Queequeg sought\r\na passage to Christian lands.
