But Queequeg vowed a vow.\r\nAlone in his canoe, he paddled off to a distant strait, which he\r\nknew the ship must pass through when she quitted the island.\r\nOn one side was a coral reef; on the other a low tongue of land,\r\ncovered with mangrove thickets that grew out into the water.\r\nHiding his canoe, still afloat, among these thickets, with its\r\nprow seaward, he sat down in the stern, paddle low in hand;\r\nand when the ship was gliding by, like a flash he darted out;\r\ngained her side; with one backward dash of his foot capsized\r\nand sank his canoe; climbed up the chains; and throwing himself\r\nat full length upon the deck, grappled a ring-bolt there,\r\nand swore not to let it go, though hacked in pieces.\r\n\r\nIn vain the captain threatened to throw him overboard; suspended a\r\ncutlass over his naked wrists; Queequeg was the son of a King,\r\nand Queequeg budged not.  Struck by his desperate dauntlessness,\r\nand his wild desire to visit Christendom, the captain at last relented,\r\nand told him he might make himself at home.  But this fine young savage--\r\nthis sea Prince of Wales, never saw the Captain's cabin.\r\nThey put him down among the sailors, and made a whaleman of him.\r\nBut like Czar Peter content to toil in the shipyards of foreign cities,\r\nQueequeg disdained no seeming ignominy, if thereby he might\r\nhappily gain the power of enlightening his untutored countrymen.\r\nFor at bottom--so he told me--he was actuated by a profound\r\ndesire to learn among the Christians, the arts whereby to make\r\nhis people still happier than they were; and more than that,\r\nstill better than they were. |                                                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |  'I see no need of this.\'\r\n\r\n"\'Excuse me for running after you, Don Sebastian; but may I\r\nalso beg that you will be particular in procuring the largest\r\nsized Evangelists you can.\'\r\n\r\n\r\n\'This is the priest, he brings you the Evangelists,\' said Don Sebastian,\r\ngravely, returning with a tall and solemn figure.\r\n\r\n"\'Let me remove my hat.  Now, venerable priest, further into the light,\r\nand hold the Holy Book before me that I may touch it.\r\n\r\n"\'So help me Heaven, and on my honor the story I have\r\ntold ye, gentlemen, is in substance and its great items, true.\r\nI know it to be true; it happened on this ball; I trod the ship;\r\nI knew the crew; I have seen and talked with Steelkilt since\r\nthe death of Radney."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 55\r\n\r\nOf the Monstrous Pictures of Whales\r\n\r\n\r\nI shall ere long paint to you as well as one can without canvas,\r\nsomething like the true form of the whale as he actually appears\r\nto the eye of the whaleman when in his own absolute body the whale\r\nis moored alongside the whaleship so that he can be fairly stepped\r\nupon there.  It may be worth while, therefore, previously to advert\r\nto those curious imaginary portraits of him which even down to\r\nthe present day confidently challenge the faith of the landsman.\r\nIt is time to set the world right in this matter, by proving such\r\npictures of the whale all wrong.\r\n\r\nIt may be that the primal source of all those pictorial delusions will\r\nbe found among the oldest Hindoo, Egyptian, and Grecian sculptures.\r\nFor ever since those inventive but unscrupulous times when on the marble\r\npanellings of temples, the pedestals of statues, and on shields,\r\nmedallions, cups, and coins, the dolphin was drawn in scales of\r\nchain-armor like Saladin\'s, and a helmeted head like St. George\'s;\r\never since then has something of the same sort of license prevailed,\r\nnot only in most popular pictures of the whale, but in many scientific\r\npresentations of him.\r\n\r\nNow, by all odds, the most ancient extant portrait anyways\r\npurporting to be the whale\'s, is to be found in the famous\r\ncavern-pagoda of Elephants, in India.  The Brahmins maintain\r\nthat in the almost endless sculptures of that immemorial pagoda,\r\nall the trades and pursuits, every conceivable avocation of man,\r\nwere prefigured ages before any of them actually came into being.\r\nNo wonder then, that in some sort our noble profession\r\nof whaling should have been there shadowed forth.  The Hindoo\r\nwhale referred to, occurs in a separate department of the wall,\r\ndepicting the incarnation of Vishnu in the form of leviathan,\r\nlearnedly known as the Matse Avatar.  But though this sculpture\r\nis half man and half whale, so as only to give the tail\r\nof the latter, yet that small section of him is all wrong.\r\nIt looks more like the tapering tail of an anaconda,\r\nthan the broad palms of the true whale\'s majestic flukes.\r\n\r\nBut go to the old Galleries, and look now at a great Christian\r\npainter\'s portrait of this fish; for he succeeds no better\r\nthan the antediluvian Hindoo.  It is Guido\'s picture of\r\nPerseus rescuing Andromeda from the sea-monster or whale.\r\nWhere did Guido get the model of such a strange creature as that?\r\nNor does Hogarth, in painting the same scene in his own\r\n"Perseus Descending," make out one whit better.  The huge\r\ncorpulence of that Hogarthian monster undulates on the surface,\r\nscarcely drawing one inch of water.  It has a sort of howdah on\r\nits back, and its distended tusked mouth into which the billows\r\nare rolling, might be taken for the Traitors\' Gate leading from\r\nthe Thames by water into the Tower.  Then, there are the Prodromus\r\nwhales of the old Scotch Sibbald, and Jonah\'s whale, as depicted\r\nin the prints of old Bibles and the cuts of old primers.\r\nWhat shall be said of these?  As for the book-binder\'s whale\r\nwinding like a vine-stalk round the stock of a descending anchor--\r\nas stamped and gilded on the backs and titlepages of many\r\nbooks both old and new--that is a very picturesque but purely\r\nfabulous creature, imitated, I take it, from the like figures\r\non antique vases.  Though universally denominated a dolphin,\r\nI nevertheless call this book-binder\'s fish an attempt at a whale;\r\nbecause it was so intended when the device was first introduced.\r\nIt was introduced by an old Italian publisher somewhere\r\nabout the 15th century, during the Revival of Learning;\r\nand in those days, and even down to a comparatively late period,\r\ndolphins were popularly supposed to be a species of the Leviathan.\r\n\r\nIn the vignettes and other embellishments of some ancient books\r\nyou will at times meet with very curious touches at the whale,\r\nwhere all manner of spouts, jets d\'eau, hot springs and cold,\r\nSaratoga and Baden-Baden, come bubbling up from his unexhausted brain.\r\nIn the title-page of the original edition of the "Advancement of Learning"\r\nyou will find some curious whales.\r\n\r\nBut quitting all these unprofessional attempts, let us glance at those\r\npictures of leviathan purporting to be sober, scientific delineations,\r\nby those who know.  In old Harris\'s collection of voyages there\r\nare some plates of whales extracted from a Dutch book of voyages,\r\nA.D. 1671, entitled "A Whaling Voyage to Spitzbergen in the ship Jonas\r\nin the Whale, Peter Peterson of Friesland, master."  In one of those\r\nplates the whales, like great rafts of logs, are represented lying\r\namong ice-isles, with white bears running over their living backs.\r\nIn another plate, the prodigious blunder is made of representing\r\nthe whale with perpendicular flukes.\r\n\r\nThen again, there is an imposing quarto, written by one Captain Colnett,\r\na Post Captain in the English navy, entitled "A Voyage round\r\nCape Horn into the South Seas, for the purpose of extending\r\nthe Spermaceti Whale Fisheries."  In this book is an outline\r\npurporting to be a "Picture of a Physeter or Spermaceti whale,\r\ndrawn by scale from one killed on the coast of Mexico, August, 1793,\r\nand hoisted on deck."  I doubt not the captain had this veracious\r\npicture taken for the benefit of his marines.  To mention but one\r\nthing about it, let me say that it has an eye which applied,\r\naccording to the accompanying scale, to a full grown sperm whale,\r\nwould make the eye of that whale a bow-window some five feet long.\r\nAh, my gallant captain, why did ye not give us Jonah looking\r\nout of that eye!\r\n\r\nNor are the most conscientious compilations of Natural History\r\nfor the benefit of the young and tender, free from the same\r\nheinousness of mistake.  Look at that popular work\r\n"Goldsmith\'s Animated Nature."  In the abridged London edition\r\nof 1807, there are plates of an alleged "whale" and a "narwhale."\r\nI do not wish to seem inelegant, but this unsightly whale\r\nlooks much like an amputated sow; and, as for the narwhale,\r\none glimpse at it is enough to amaze one, that in this nineteenth\r\ncentury such a hippogriff could be palmed for genuine upon\r\nany intelligent public of schoolboys.\r\n\r\nThen, again, in 1825, Bernard Germain, Count de Lacepede,\r\na great naturalist, published a scientific systemized whale book,\r\nwherein are several pictures of the different species of\r\nthe Leviathan.  All these are not only incorrect, but the picture\r\nof the Mysticetus or Greenland whale (that is to say the Right\r\nwhale), even Scoresby, a long experienced man as touching\r\nthat species, declares not to have its counterpart in nature.\r\n\r\nBut the placing of the cap-sheaf to all this blundering business\r\nwas reserved for the scientific Frederick Cuvier, brother to the\r\nfamous Baron.  In 1836, he published a Natural History of Whales,\r\nin which he gives what he calls a picture of the Sperm Whale.\r\nBefore showing that picture to any Nantucketer, you had best\r\nprovide for your summary retreat from Nantucket.  In a word,\r\nFrederick Cuvier\'s Sperm Whale is not a Sperm Whale, but a squash.\r\nOf course, he never had the benefit of a whaling voyage (such men\r\nseldom have), but whence he derived that picture, who can tell?\r\nPerhaps he got it as his scientific predecessor in the same field,\r\nDesmarest, got one of his authentic abortions; that is, from a\r\nChinese drawing.  And what sort of lively lads with the pencil\r\nthose Chinese are, many queer cups and saucers inform us.\r\n\r\nAs for the sign-painters\' whales seen in the streets hanging\r\nover the shops of oil-dealers, what shall be said of them?\r\nThey are generally Richard III.  whales, with dromedary humps,\r\nand very savage; breakfasting on three or four sailor tarts,\r\nthat is whaleboats full of mariners:  their deformities\r\nfloundering in seas of blood and blue paint.\r\n\r\nBut these manifold mistakes in depicting the whale are not so very\r\nsurprising after all.  Consider!  Most of the scientific drawings have\r\nbeen taken from the stranded fish; and these are about as correct as a\r\ndrawing of a wrecked ship, with broken back, would correctly represent\r\nthe noble animal itself in all its undashed pride of hull and spars.\r\nThough elephants have stood for their full-lengths, the living\r\nLeviathan has never yet fairly floated himself for his portrait.\r\nThe living whale, in his full majesty and significance, is only\r\nto be seen at sea in unfathomable waters; and afloat the vast\r\nbulk of him is out of sight, like a launched line-of-battle ship;\r\nand out of that element it is a thing eternally impossible for mortal\r\nman to hoist him bodily into the air, so as to preserve all his mighty\r\nswells and undulations.  And, not to speak of the highly presumable\r\ndifference of contour between a young suckling whale and a full-grown\r\nPlatonian Leviathan; yet, even in the case of one of those young\r\nsucking whales hoisted to a ship\'s deck, such is then the outlandish,\r\neel-like, limbered, varying shape of him, that his precise expression\r\nthe devil himself could not catch.\r\n\r\nBut it may be fancied, that from the naked skeleton of the stranded whale,\r\naccurate hints may be derived touching his true form.  Not at all.\r\nFor it is one of the more curious things about this Leviathan,\r\nthat his skeleton gives very little idea of his general shape.\r\nThough Jeremy Bentham\'s skeleton, which hangs for candelabra\r\nin the library of one of his executors, correctly conveys the idea\r\nof a burly-browed utilitarian old gentleman, with all Jeremy\'s\r\nother leading personal characteristics; yet nothing of this\r\nkind could be inferred from any leviathan\'s articulated bones.\r\nIn fact, as the great Hunter says, the mere skeleton of the whale\r\nbears the same relation to the fully invested and padded animal\r\nas the insect does to the chrysalis that so roundingly envelopes it.\r\nThis peculiarity is strikingly evinced in the head, as in some part\r\nof this book will be incidentally shown.  It is also very curiously\r\ndisplayed in the side fin, the bones of which almost exactly answer\r\nto the bones of the human hand, minus only the thumb.  This fin has\r\nfour regular bone-fingers, the index, middle, ring, and little finger.\r\nBut all these are permanently lodged in their fleshy covering,\r\nas the human fingers in an artificial covering.  "However recklessly\r\nthe whale may sometimes serve us," said humorous Stubb one day,\r\n"he can never be truly said to handle us without mittens."\r\n\r\nFor all these reasons, then, any way you may look at it,\r\nyou must needs conclude that the great Leviathan is that one\r\ncreature in the world which must remain unpainted to the last.\r\nTrue, one portrait may hit the mark much nearer than another,\r\nbut none can hit it with any very considerable degree of exactness.\r\nSo there is no earthly way of finding out precisely what\r\nthe whale really looks like.  And the only mode in which you\r\ncan derive even a tolerable idea of his living contour,\r\nis by going a whaling yourself; but by so doing, you run\r\nno small risk of being eternally stove and sunk by him.\r\nWherefore, it seems to me you had best not be too fastidious\r\nin your curiosity touching this Leviathan.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 56\r\n\r\nOf the Less Erroneous Pictures of Whales and the True Pictures\r\nof Whaling Scenes\r\n\r\n\r\nIn connexion with the monstrous pictures of whales, I am strongly\r\ntempted here to enter upon those still more monstrous stories of them\r\nwhich are to be found in certain books, both ancient and modern,\r\nespecially in Pliny, Purchas, Hackluyt, Harris, Cuvier, &c. But I\r\npass that matter by.\r\n\r\nI know of only four published outlines of the great\r\nSperm Whale; Colnett\'s, Huggins\'s, Frederick Cuvier\'s, and Beale\'s. In\r\nthe previous chapter Colnett and Cuvier have been referred to.\r\nHuggins\'s is far better than theirs; but, by great odds,\r\nBeale\'s is the best.  All Beale\'s drawings of this whale\r\nare good, excepting the middle figure in the picture of three\r\nwhales in various attitudes, capping his second chapter.\r\nHis frontispiece, boats attacking Sperm Whales, though no doubt\r\ncalculated to excite the civil scepticism of some parlor men,\r\nis admirably correct and life-like in its general effect.\r\nSome of the Sperm Whale drawings in J. Ross Browne are pretty\r\ncorrect in contour; but they are wretchedly engraved.\r\nThat is not his fault though.\r\n\r\nOf the Right Whale, the best outline pictures are in Scoresby;\r\nbut they are drawn on too small a scale to convey a desirable impression.\r\nHe has but one picture of whaling scenes, and this is a sad deficiency,\r\nbecause it is by such pictures only, when at all well done, that you\r\ncan derive anything like a truthful idea of the living whale as seen\r\nby his living hunters.\r\n\r\nBut, taken for all in all, by far the finest, though in\r\nsome details not the most correct, presentations of whales\r\nand whaling scenes to be anywhere found, are two large\r\nFrench engravings, well executed, and taken from paintings by\r\none Garnery.  Respectively, they represent attacks on the Sperm\r\nand Right Whale.  In the first engraving a noble Sperm Whale\r\nis depicted in full majesty of might, just risen beneath the boat\r\nfrom the profundities of the ocean, and bearing high in the.\r\nair upon his back the terrific wreck of the stoven planks.\r\nThe prow of the boat is partially unbroken, and is drawn just\r\nbalancing upon the monster\'s spine; and standing in that prow,\r\nfor that one single incomputable flash of time, you behold\r\nan oarsman, half shrouded by the incensed boiling spout of\r\nthe whale, and in the act of leaping, as if from a precipice.\r\nThe action of the whole thing is wonderfully good and true.\r\nThe half-emptied line-tub floats on the whitened sea;\r\nthe wooden poles of the spilled harpoons obliquely bob in it;\r\nthe heads of the swimming crew are scattered about the whale\r\nin contrasting expressions of affright; while in the black\r\nstormy distance the ship is bearing down upon the scene.\r\nSerious fault might be found with the anatomical details\r\nof this whale, but let that pass; since, for the life of me,\r\nI could not draw so good a one.\r\n\r\nIn the second engraving, the boat is in the act of drawing alongside\r\nthe barnacled flank of a large running Right Whale, that rolls\r\nhis black weedy bulk in the sea like some mossy rock-slide from\r\nthe Patagonian cliffs.  His jets are erect, full, and black like soot;\r\nso that from so abounding a smoke in the chimney, you would think\r\nthere must be a brave supper cooking in the great bowels below.\r\nSea fowls are pecking at the small crabs, shell-fish, and other sea\r\ncandies and maccaroni, which the Right Whale sometimes carries on\r\nhis pestilent back.  And all the while the thick-lipped leviathan\r\nis rushing through the deep, leaving tons of tumultuous white curds\r\nin his wake, and causing the slight boat to rock in the swells\r\nlike a skiff caught nigh the paddle-wheels of an ocean steamer.\r\nThus, the fore-ground is all raging commotion; but behind,\r\nin admirable artistic contrast, is the glassy level of a sea becalmed,\r\nthe drooping unstarched sails of the powerless ship, and the inert\r\nmass of a dead whale, a conquered fortress, with the flag of capture\r\nlazily hanging from the whale-pole inserted into his spout-hole.\r\n\r\nWho Garnery the painter is, or was, I know not.  But my life\r\nfor it he was either practically conversant with his subject,\r\nor else marvellously tutored by some experienced whaleman.\r\nThe French are the lads for painting action.  Go and gaze upon\r\nall the paintings in Europe, and where will you find such a\r\ngallery of living and breathing commotion on canvas, as in that\r\ntriumphal hall at Versailles; where the beholder fights his way,\r\npell-mell, through the consecutive great battles of France;\r\nwhere every sword seems a flash of the Northern Lights,\r\nand the successive armed kings and Emperors dash by, like a\r\ncharge of crowned centaurs?  Not wholly unworthy of a place\r\nin that gallery, are these sea battle-pieces of Garnery.\r\n\r\nThe natural aptitude of the French for seizing the picturesqueness\r\nof things seems to be peculiarly evinced in what paintings\r\nand engravings they have of their whaling scenes.\r\nWith not one tenth of England\'s experience in the fishery,\r\nand not the thousandth part of that of the Americans, they have\r\nnevertheless furnished both nations with the only finished sketches\r\nat all capable of conveying the real spirit of the whale hunt.\r\nFor the most part, the English and American whale draughtsmen\r\nseem entirely content with presenting the mechanical\r\noutline of things, such as the vacant profile of the whale;\r\nwhich, so far as picturesqueness of effect is concerned,\r\nis about tantamount to sketching the profile of a pyramid.\r\nEven Scoresby, the justly renowned Right whaleman,\r\nafter giving us a stiff full length of the Greenland whale,\r\nand three or four delicate miniatures of narwhales and porpoises,\r\ntreats us to a series of classical engravings of boat hooks,\r\nchopping knives, and grapnels; and with the microscopic diligence\r\nof a Leuwenhoeck submits to the inspection of a shivering world\r\nninety-six fac-similes of magnified Arctic snow crystals.\r\nI mean no disparagement to the excellent voyager (I honor him\r\nfor a veteran), but in so important a matter it was certainly\r\nan oversight not to have procured for every crystal a sworn\r\naffidavit taken before a Greenland Justice of the Peace.\r\n\r\nIn addition to those fine engravings from Garnery, there are two\r\nother French engravings worthy of note, by some one who subscribes\r\nhimself "H. Durand." Pythagoras, that in bright Greece,\r\ntwo thousand years ago, did die, so good, so wise, so mild; I sailed\r\nwith thee along the Peruvian coast last voyage--and, foolish as I am,\r\ntaught thee, a green simple boy, how to splice a rope.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 99\r\n\r\nThe Doubloon\r\n\r\n\r\nEre now it has been related how Ahab was wont to pace his quarter-deck,\r\ntaking regular turns at either limit, the binnacle and mainmast;\r\nbut in the multiplicity of other things requiring narration it\r\nhas not been added how that sometimes in these walks, when most\r\nplunged in his mood, he was wont to pause in turn at each spot,\r\nand stand there strangely eyeing the particular object before him.\r\nWhen he halted before the binnacle, with his glance fastened on\r\nthe pointed needle in the compass, that glance shot like a javelin\r\nwith the pointed intensity of his purpose; and when resuming his walk\r\nhe again paused before the mainmast, then, as the same riveted glance\r\nfastened upon the riveted gold coin there, he still wore the same\r\naspect of nailed firmness, only dashed with a certain wild longing,\r\nif not hopefulness.\r\n\r\nBut one morning, turning to pass the doubloon, he seemed to be newly\r\nattracted by the strange figures and inscriptions stamped on it,\r\nas though now for the first time beginning to interpret for himself\r\nin some monomaniac way whatever significance might lurk in them.\r\nAnd some certain significance lurks in all things, else all things\r\nare little worth, and the round world itself but an empty cipher,\r\nexcept to sell by the cartload, as they do hills about Boston,\r\nto fill up some morass in the Milky Way.\r\n\r\nNow this doubloon was of purest, virgin gold, raked somewhere\r\nout of the heart of gorgeous hills, whence, east and west,\r\nover golden sands, the head-waters of many a Pactolus flows.\r\nAnd though now nailed amidst all the rustiness of iron bolts\r\nand the verdigris of copper spikes, yet, untouchable and immaculate\r\nto any foulness, it still preserved its Quito glow.  Nor, though placed\r\namongst a ruthless crew and every hour passed by ruthless hands,\r\nand through the livelong nights shrouded with thick darkness\r\nwhich might cover any pilfering approach, nevertheless every\r\nsunrise found the doubloon where the sunset last left it last.\r\nFor it was set apart and sanctified to one awe-striking end;\r\nand however wanton in their sailor ways, one and all,\r\nthe mariners revered it as the white whale\'s talisman.\r\nSometimes they talked it over in the weary watch by night,\r\nwondering whose it was to be at last, and whether he would ever\r\nlive to spend it.\r\n\r\nNow those noble golden coins of South America are as medals of the sun\r\nand tropic token-pieces. Here palms, alpacas, and volcanoes; sun\'s disks\r\nand stars, ecliptics, horns-of-plenty, and rich banners waving,\r\nare in luxuriant profusion stamped; so that the precious gold seems\r\nalmost to derive an added preciousness and enhancing glories,\r\nby passing through those fancy mints, so Spanishly poetic.\r\n\r\nIt so chanced that the doubloon of the Pequod was a most wealthy\r\nexample of these things.  On its round border it bore the letters,\r\nREPUBLICA DEL ECUADOR:  QUITO.  So this bright coin came from a country\r\nplanted in the middle of the world, and beneath the great equator,\r\nand named after it; and it had been cast midway up the Andes,\r\nin the unwaning clime that knows no autumn.  Zoned by those letters\r\nyou saw the likeness of three Andes\' summits; from one a flame;\r\na tower on another; on the third a crowing cock; while arching\r\nover all was a segment of the partitioned zodiac, the signs all\r\nmarked with their usual cabalistics, and the keystone sun entering\r\nthe equinoctial point at Libra.\r\n\r\nBefore this equatorial coin, Ahab, not unobserved by others,\r\nwas now pausing.\r\n\r\n"There\'s something ever egotistical in mountain-tops\r\nand towers, and all other grand and lofty things; look here,--\r\nthree peaks as proud as Lucifer. and herein are indirectly comprised\r\nmany minor contingencies, all partaking of this one grand feature.\r\nFor example,--after a weary and perilous chase and capture of a whale,\r\nthe body may get loose from the ship by reason of a violent storm;\r\nand drifting far away to leeward, be retaken by a second whaler, who,\r\nin a calm, snugly tows it alongside, without risk of life or line.\r\nThus the most vexatious and violent disputes would often arise between\r\nthe fishermen, were there not some written or unwritten, universal,\r\nundisputed law applicable to all cases.\r\n\r\nPerhaps the only formal whaling code authorized by legislative enactment,\r\nwas that of Holland. | Who is Fedallah?                                                                      | In the given text, Fedallah is described as an old Oriental man who serves on the ivory Pequod. He is a lookout, standing at the main-mast head at night, and often announces the sighting of a mysterious moonlight whale spout that seems to be following the ship.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     | ['But one cannot sustain an indifferent air concerning Fedallah.  He was\r\nsuch a creature as civilized, domestic people in the temperate zone\r\nonly see in their dreams, and that but dimly; but the like of whom\r\nnow and then glide among the unchanging Asiatic communities,\r\nespecially the Oriental isles to the east of the continent--\r\nthose insulated, immemorial, unalterable countries, which even in\r\nthese modern days still preserve much of the ghostly aboriginalness\r\nof earth\'s primal generations, when the memory of the first\r\nman was a distinct recollection, and all men his descendants,\r\nunknowing whence he came, eyed each other as real phantoms, and asked\r\nof the sun and the moon why they were created and to what end;\r\nwhen though, according to Genesis, the angels indeed consorted with\r\nthe daughters of men, the devils also, add the uncanonical Robbins,\r\nindulged in mundane amours.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 51\r\n\r\nThe Spirit-Spout\r\n\r\n\r\nDays, weeks passed, and under easy sail, the ivory Pequod\r\nhad slowly swept across four several cruising-grounds;\r\nthat off the Azores; off the Cape de Verdes; on the Plate\r\n(so called), being off the mouth of the Rio de la Plata;\r\nand the Carrol Ground, an unstaked, watery locality,\r\nsoutherly from St. Helena.\r\n\r\nIt was while gliding through these latter waters that one\r\nserene and moonlight night, when all the waves rolled by like\r\nscrolls of silver; and, by their soft, suffusing seethings,\r\nmade what seemed a silvery silence, not a solitude; on such a\r\nsilent night a silvery jet was seen far in advance of the white\r\nbubbles at the bow.  Lit up by the moon, it looked celestial;\r\nseemed some plumed and glittering god uprising from the sea.\r\nFedallah first descried this jet.  For of these moonlight nights,\r\nit was his wont to mount to the main-mast head, and stand\r\na look-out there, with the same precision as if it had been day.\r\nAnd yet, though herds of whales were seen by night, not one\r\nwhaleman in a hundred would venture a lowering for them.\r\nYou may think with what emotions, then, the seamen beheld\r\nthis old Oriental perched aloft at such unusual hours;\r\nhis turban and the moon, companions in one sky.  But when,\r\nafter spending his uniform interval there for several successive\r\nnights without uttering a single sound; when, after all this silence,\r\nhis unearthly voice was heard announcing that silvery, moon-lit jet,\r\nevery reclining mariner started to his feet as if some winged\r\nspirit had lighted in the rigging, and hailed the mortal crew.\r\n"There she blows!"  Had the trump of judgment blown,\r\nthey could not have quivered more; yet still they felt no terror;\r\nrather pleasure.  For though it was a most unwonted hour,\r\nyet so impressive was the cry, and so deliriously exciting,\r\nthat almost every soul on board instinctively desired a lowering.\r\n\r\nWalking the deck with quick, side-lunging strides, Ahab commanded\r\nthe t\'gallant sails and royals to be set, and every stunsail spread.\r\nThe best man in the ship must take the helm.  Then, with every\r\nmast-head manned, the piled-up craft rolled down before the wind.\r\nThe strange, upheaving, lifting tendency of the taffrail breeze\r\nfilling the hollows of so many sails, made the buoyant, hovering deck\r\nto feel like air beneath the feet; while still she rushed along,\r\nas if two antagonistic influences were struggling in her--one to mount\r\ndirect to heaven, the other to drive yawingly to some horizontal goal.\r\nAnd had you watched Ahab\'s face that night, you would have thought\r\nthat in him also two different things were warring.  While his one live\r\nleg made lively echoes along the deck, every stroke of his dead limb\r\nsounded like a coffin-tap. On life and death this old man walked.\r\nBut though the ship so swiftly sped, and though from every eye,\r\nlike arrows, the eager glances shot, yet the silvery jet was no\r\nmore seen that night.  Every sailor swore he saw it once, but not\r\na second time.\r\n\r\nThis midnight-spout had almost grown a forgotten thing, when,\r\nsome days after, lo! at the same silent hour, it was again announced:\r\nagain it was descried by all; but upon making sail to overtake it,\r\nonce more it disappeared as if it had never been.  And so it served\r\nus night after night, till no one heeded it but to wonder at it.\r\nMysteriously jetted into the clear moonlight, or starlight,\r\nas the case might be; disappearing again for one whole day,\r\nor two days, or three; and somehow seeming at every distinct\r\nrepetition to be advancing still further and further in our van,\r\nthis solitary jet seemed for ever alluring us on.\r\n\r\nNor with the immemorial superstition of their race,\r\nand in accordance with the preternaturalness, as it seemed,\r\nwhich in many things invested the Pequod, were there wanting\r\nsome of the seamen who swore that whenever and wherever descried;\r\nat however remote times, or in however far apart latitudes\r\nand longitudes, that unnearable spout was cast by one selfsame whale;\r\nand that whale, Moby Dick.  For a time, there reigned, too, a sense\r\nof peculiar dread at this flitting apparition, as if it were\r\ntreacherously beckoning us on and on, in order that the monster\r\nmight turn round upon us, and rend us at last in the remotest\r\nand most savage seas.\r\n\r\nThese temporary apprehensions, so vague but so awful, derived a\r\nwondrous potency from the contrasting serenity of the weather,\r\nin which, beneath all its blue blandness, some thought there\r\nlurked a devilish charm, as for days and days we voyaged along,\r\nthrough seas so wearily, lonesomely mild, that all space,\r\nin repugnance to our vengeful errand, seemed vacating itself\r\nof life before our urn-like prow.\r\n\r\nBut, at last, when turning to the eastward, the Cape winds\r\nbegan howling around us, and we rose and fell upon the long,\r\ntroubled seas that are there; when the ivory-tusked Pequod sharply\r\nbowed to the blast, and gored the dark waves in her madness, till,\r\nlike showers of silver chips, the foamflakes flew over her bulwarks;\r\nthen all this desolate vacuity of life went away, but gave place\r\nto sights more dismal than before.\r\n\r\nClose to our bows, strange forms in the water darted hither and thither\r\nbefore us; while thick in our rear flew the inscrutable sea-ravens. And\r\nevery morning, perched on our stays, rows of these birds were seen;\r\nand spite of our hootings, for a long time obstinately clung to the hemp,\r\nas though they deemed our ship some drifting, uninhabited craft;\r\na thing appointed to desolation, and therefore fit roosting-place\r\nfor their homeless selves.  And heaved and heaved, still unrestingly\r\nheaved the black sea, as if its vast tides were a conscience;\r\nand the great mundane soul were in anguish and remorse for the long\r\nsin and suffering it had bred.\r\n\r\nCape of Good Hope, do they call ye?  Rather Cape Tormentoto,\r\nas called of yore; for long allured by the perfidious silences\r\nthat before had attended us, we found ourselves launched into this\r\ntormented sea, where guilty beings transformed into those fowls\r\nand these fish, seemed condemned to swim on everlastingly without\r\nany haven in store, or beat that black air without any horizon.\r\nBut calm, snow-white, and unvarying; still directing its fountain\r\nof feathers to the sky; still beckoning us on from before,\r\nthe solitary jet would at times be descried.\r\n\r\nDuring all this blackness of the elements, Ahab, though assuming\r\nfor the time the almost continual command of the drenched and\r\ndangerous deck, manifested the gloomiest reserve; and more seldom\r\nthan ever addressed his mates.  In tempestuous times like these,\r\nafter everything above and aloft has been secured, nothing more\r\ncan be done but passively to await the issue of the gale.\r\nThen Captain and crew become practical fatalists.  So, with his\r\nivory leg inserted into its accustomed hole, and with one hand\r\nfirmly grasping a shroud, Ahab for hours and hours would stand\r\ngazing dead to windward, while an occasional squall of sleet\r\nor snow would all but congeal his very eyelashes together.\r\nMeantime, the crew driven from the forward part of the ship\r\nby the perilous seas that burstingly broke over its bows,\r\nstood in a line along the bulwarks in the waist; and the better\r\nto guard against the leaping waves, each man had slipped\r\nhimself into a sort of bowline secured to the rail, in which\r\nhe swung as in a loosened belt.  Few or no words were spoken;\r\nand the silent ship, as if manned by painted sailors in wax,\r\nday after day tore on through all the swift madness and gladness\r\nof the demoniac waves.  By night the same muteness of humanity\r\nbefore the shrieks of the ocean prevailed; still in silence the men\r\nswung in the bowlines; still wordless Ahab stood up to the blast.\r\nEven when wearied nature seemed demanding repose he would not seek\r\nthat repose in his hammock.  Never could Starbuck forget the old\r\nman\'s aspect, when one night going down into the cabin to mark\r\nhow the barometer stood, he saw him with closed eyes sitting\r\nstraight in his floor-screwed chair; the rain and half-melted\r\nsleet of the storm from which he had some time before emerged,\r\nstill slowly dripping from the unremoved hat and coat.\r\nOn the table beside him lay unrolled one of those charts\r\nof tides and currents which have previously been spoken of.\r\nHis lantern swung from his tightly clenched hand.\r\nThough the body was erect, the head was thrown back so that\r\nthe closed eyes were pointed towards the needle of the tell-tale\r\nthat swung from a beam in the ceiling.*\r\n\r\n\r\n*The cabin-compass is called the tell-tale, because without\r\ngoing to the compass at the helm, the Captain, while below,\r\ncan inform himself of the course of the ship.\r\n\r\n\r\nTerrible old man! It\'s an honor;\r\nI consider it an honor.  Listen, wise Stubb.  In old England\r\nthe greatest lords think it great glory to be slapped by a queen,\r\nand made garter-knights of; but, be your boast, Stubb, that ye were\r\nkicked by old Ahab, and made a wise man of.  Remember what I say;\r\nbe kicked by him; account his kicks honors; and on no account kick back;\r\nfor you can\'t help yourself, wise Stubb. Ahab has that that\'s bloody on his mind.\r\nBut, mum; he comes this way."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 32\r\n\r\nCetology\r\n\r\n\r\nAlready we are boldly launched upon the deep; but soon we\r\nshall be lost in its unshored harborless immensities.\r\nEre that come to pass; ere the Pequod\'s weedy hull rolls\r\nside by side with the barnacled hulls of the leviathan;\r\nat the outset it is but well to attend to a matter almost\r\nindispensable to a thorough appreciative understanding of the more\r\nspecial leviathanic revelations and allusions of all sorts\r\nwhich are to follow.\r\n\r\nIt is some systematized exhibition of the whale in his broad genera,\r\nthat I would now fain put before you.  Yet is it no easy task.\r\nThe classification of the constituents of a chaos, nothing less\r\nis here essayed.  Listen to what the best and latest authorities\r\nhave laid down.\r\n\r\n"No branch of Zoology is so much involved as that which is\r\nentitled Cetology," says Captain Scoresby, A.D. 1820.\r\n\r\n"It is not my intention, were it in my power, to enter into the inquiry\r\nas to the true method of dividing the cetacea into groups and\r\nfamilies.... Utter confusion exists among the historians of this animal"\r\n(sperm whale), says Surgeon Beale, A.D. 1839.\r\n\r\n"Unfitness to pursue our research in the unfathomable waters."\r\n"Impenetrable veil covering our knowledge of the cetacea."\r\n"A field strewn with thorns."  "All these incomplete indications\r\nbut serve to torture us naturalists."\r\n\r\nThus speak of the whale, the great Cuvier, and John Hunter, and Lesson,\r\nthose lights of zoology and anatomy.  Nevertheless, though of real\r\nknowledge there be little, yet of books there are a plenty;\r\nand so in some small degree, with cetology, or the science of whales.\r\nMany are the men, small and great, old and new, landsmen and seamen,\r\nwho have at large or in little, written of the whale.
